title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
Australia’s 2019–20 “Black Summer” bushfires were among the most devastating in history—34 people lost their lives, thousands of homes were destroyed, and millions of hectares burned.
These events raised an urgent question:
> Has climate change increased the likelihood of extreme bushfi44re weather in southeast Australia?
This blog summarises the findings of van Oldenborgh et al. (2021), who combined observed weather records and climate-model simulations to quantify the human influence on bushfire risk.
Their results show that the probability of an extreme Fire Weather Index (FWI) season is now about 30% higher than it was in a pre-industrial climate.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
Australia’s 2019–20 “Black Summer” killed 34 people, destroyed thousands of homes, and caused major environmental damage.
This post asks a simple, public-facing question:

> Has human-driven climate change increased the chance of extreme fire weather in south-east Australia?
Researchers comparing today’s climate with a pre-industrial world find that the chance of an extreme Fire Weather Index (FWI) season is now about 30% higher.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
Data Description
The study integrates both observations and model experiments

ERA5 Reanalysis (1979–2020) – temperature, rainfall and drought indices (Hersbach et al., 2019).

Bureau of Meteorology Fire Weather Index (FWI) – the key indicator of bushfire danger (Dowdy 2018).

Climate models (CMIP5/6 ensembles) – simulations with and without greenhouse gases to separate human influence (van Oldenborgh et al., 2021).

An “extreme season” was defined as any year with a seasonal maximum FWI ≥ 2019–20.
Event probabilities were estimated using extreme-value fits for both climates; the Probability Ratio (PR) = current / pre-industrial risk.
Below is a simple visualisation of this idea (not real data but representative of their result).

library(ggplot2)
df <- data.frame(pr = 1.3, lo = 1.1, hi = 1.6)
ggplot(df, aes(x="PR")) +
  geom_col(aes(y=pr), fill="#006DAE") +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=lo, ymax=hi), width=0.15) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim=c(0,2)) +
  labs(y="Current / Pre-industrial risk", x=NULL) +
  theme_minimal(base_size=13)







Figure 1: Estimated Probability Ratio (PR) for an extreme FWI season under current vs pre-industrial climate.

These events raised an urgent question:

This blog summarises the findings of van Oldenborgh et al. (2021), who combined observed weather records and climate-model simulations to quantify the human influence on bushfire risk.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
🌏 Data and Findings
The study used multiple independent data sources:

ERA5 Reanalysis (1979–2020) — records of temperature, rainfall, humidity, and wind (Hersbach et al., 2019)

Bureau of Meteorology Fire Weather Index (FWI) — a measure of daily bushfire danger (Dowdy 2018)

Climate-model ensembles (CMIP5/6) — simulations comparing current and pre-industrial climate worlds (van Oldenborgh et al., 2021)

Together, these sources reveal a clear upward shift in fire-weather risk.
Across all datasets, extreme FWI seasons are roughly 30% more likely in the present climate, and extreme heat events occur about twice as often, while dryness signals remain weak or uncertain.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
📈 Analysis

🔹 Figure 1 – Probability Ratio (PR)






Figure 1



Figure 1. Probability ratio (PR) for an FWI as high as observed in 2019–20 or higher, based on multiple climate models.
Source: van Oldenborgh et al. (2021), Figure 6(a).
As shown in Figure 1, all five model ensembles (ERA5, CanESM2, EC-Earth, IPSL-CM6, and weather@home) show PR > 1, meaning extreme fire-weather seasons are now more likely than before industrialization.


🔹 Table 1 – Key Findings



Table 1: Summary of the main attribution results for southeast Australia.

Table 1 summaries the evidence in plain language.
Together, these findings directly address the original question:
Yes — climate change has measurably increased the likelihood of extreme fire-weather seasons.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
🧠 Conclusion
Human-induced climate change has shifted Australia’s baseline bushfire risk upward.
Even though natural variability still affects individual seasons, the overall odds are now “loaded” toward hotter, more dangerous summers.
To prepare for this new normal, researchers and decision-makers should:
1. Integrate climate-scenario data into bushfire management and planning.
2. Strengthen early-warning systems and community education.
3. Continue fuel-load and land-use management to reduce fire intensity.
As (Oldenborgh et al. 2021) and (Dowdy 2018) highlight, adapting to this warmer world requires both mitigation of greenhouse emissions and practical resilience strategies.
